issue.title: Translate to IN + subquery when possible instead of EXISTS

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
~This builds on top of #30956 (ignore first commit)~ to translate to IN+subquery where possible (see #30955).

Closes #30955

body: I would like to tackle this

issue.title: Optimize away DISTINCT inside IN/EXISTS/set operations

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
This PR optimizes away `DISTINCT` when immediately inside IN/EXISTS/set operations.

Fixes #31016.

body:
While working on this I noticed that there are other cases in which DISTINCT can be safely removed:
 - when `Take`ing 0 or 1 elements (in general, when limiting to 1 element with no skip; this includes `.First[OrDefault]()` & co)
 - when doing a `MAX` or `MIN` over the distinct

I will open other issues on this

issue.title: Remove DISTINCT inside singleton queries

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Issues that have been approved but are not scheduled a specific release.

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
When a (sub)query results in 0 or 1 elements (`First()`, `Last()`, `FirstOrDefault()`, `LastOrDefault()`, `Take(0/1)`, ...), DISTINCT has no effect and can be removed.

Conceptually this is a continuation of #31016

issue.title: Remove DISTINCT inside MIN/MAX operations

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
When a value in a query computed as a MAX or MIN of a subquery, DISTINCT has no effect and can be removed.

Conceptually this is a continuation of https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/31016
